<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 796, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the mass of a metre rule using two methods. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 210, 121]]<|/det|> **Method 1.** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 576, 153]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 160, 779, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 271, 532, 289]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 504, 320]]<|/det|> You are provided with a \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass, labelled \(\mathbf{X}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 333, 143, 351]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 333, 180, 351]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 333, 875, 367]]<|/det|> Place the mass \(\mathbf{X}\) on the rule so that its centre is at a distance \(d = 5.0 \text{cm}\) from the zero end of the rule, as shown in Fig. 1.1. Another student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) may not be equal to \(\frac{R_{1}}{3}\) because the lamp filaments are hotter when the lamps are connected in parallel than when the lamps are connected in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 352, 875, 388]]<|/det|>
State one piece of evidence that shows that the lamp filaments are hotter in the parallel circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[789, 460, 875, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]
